quiz.title: Unit 3: Motion & Graphs (Quiz 1)
quiz.subtitle: Describing Motion: Position, Velocity, and Acceleration (50 Questions)
quiz.subject: Physics

questions.question: Which of the following best defines motion?
options: The change in position of an object over time
The speed at which an object travels
The force required to move an object
questions.explanation: Motion is defined as the change in an object's position relative to a reference point over time.

questions.question: What is the difference between distance and displacement?
options: Distance is always greater than displacement
Distance is a vector quantity, displacement is scalar
Distance measures total path length, displacement measures change in position
They are the same physical quantity
questions.explanation: Distance is the total path length traveled (scalar), while displacement is the straight-line change in position from start to end (vector).

questions.question: A car travels 40 km north, then 30 km south. What is the total distance traveled?
questions.explanation: Distance is the sum of all path lengths: 40 km + 30 km = 70 km.

questions.question: A car travels 40 km north, then 30 km south. What is the displacement?
questions.explanation: Displacement is the net change in position: 40 km north - 30 km south = 10 km north.

questions.question: What is the key difference between speed and velocity?
options: Speed is always faster than velocity
Velocity includes direction, speed does not
Speed is a vector quantity, velocity is scalar
They are measured in different units
questions.explanation: Speed is scalar (magnitude only), velocity is vector (magnitude and direction).

questions.question: A runner completes one lap around a 400 m track in 50 seconds. What is their average speed?
questions.explanation: Average speed = total distance / time = 400 m / 50 s = 8 m/s.

questions.question: A runner completes one lap around a 400 m track in 50 seconds. What is their average velocity?
questions.explanation: Average velocity = displacement / time. Since they return to the starting point, displacement = 0, so velocity = 0 m/s.

questions.question: Which quantity is defined as the rate of change of velocity?
questions.explanation: Acceleration is the rate at which velocity changes with time.

questions.question: A car's velocity changes from 20 m/s to 30 m/s in 5 seconds. What is its acceleration?
questions.explanation: Acceleration = (final velocity - initial velocity) / time = (30 - 20) m/s / 5 s = 2 m/s².

questions.question: Which of the following represents negative acceleration?
questions.explanation: Negative acceleration (deceleration) occurs when an object slows down in its direction of motion.

questions.question: If an object has zero acceleration, what can we say about its motion?
options: It is moving at constant velocity
questions.explanation: Zero acceleration means no change in velocity - the object moves at constant speed in a straight line.

questions.question: A bicycle travels 150 meters in 30 seconds. What is its average speed?
questions.explanation: Average speed = distance / time = 150 m / 30 s = 5 m/s.

questions.question: What does the slope of a position-time graph represent?
questions.explanation: The slope of a position-time graph equals the velocity of the object.

questions.question: A student walks 3 km east to school, then 3 km west back home. What is their total displacement?
questions.explanation: Displacement is the net change in position. Starting and ending at home means zero displacement.

questions.question: Which of the following is a vector quantity?
questions.explanation: Velocity has both magnitude and direction, making it a vector quantity.

questions.question: A car accelerates from rest to 25 m/s in 10 seconds. What is its acceleration?
questions.explanation: Acceleration = (25 m/s - 0 m/s) / 10 s = 2.5 m/s².

questions.question: If velocity is constant, what is the acceleration?
questions.explanation: Constant velocity means no change in velocity, so acceleration is zero.

questions.question: A ball rolls down a hill, increasing its speed from 2 m/s to 8 m/s in 3 seconds. What is its acceleration?
questions.explanation: Acceleration = (8 m/s - 2 m/s) / 3 s = 6 m/s / 3 s = 2 m/s².

questions.question: What is the SI unit of acceleration?
questions.explanation: Acceleration is change in velocity (m/s) per time (s), so units are m/s².

questions.question: A person walks 100 m north, then 100 m south. Their displacement is:
questions.explanation: They return to their starting position, so net displacement is zero.

questions.question: Which statement about motion is always true?
options: Distance traveled is greater than displacement
Displacement can be greater than distance
Average speed equals average velocity magnitude
questions.explanation: Distance is always greater than or equal to displacement, since distance follows the actual path while displacement is straight-line.

questions.question: A car travels 60 km in 45 minutes. What is its average speed in km/h?
questions.explanation: 45 minutes = 0.75 hours. Average speed = 60 km / 0.75 h = 80 km/h.

questions.question: An object moving with constant speed in a circle has:
questions.explanation: Even with constant speed, circular motion involves changing direction, so velocity changes and acceleration is not zero.

questions.question: What does a horizontal line on a velocity-time graph indicate?
questions.explanation: A horizontal line on a velocity-time graph means velocity is constant (zero acceleration).

questions.question: A train slows down from 30 m/s to 10 m/s in 8 seconds. What is its acceleration?
questions.explanation: Acceleration = (10 - 30) m/s / 8 s = -20 m/s / 8 s = -2.5 m/s² (negative indicates deceleration).

questions.question: A hiker walks 5 km east, then 3 km north. What is the total distance traveled?
questions.explanation: Distance = sum of all paths = 5 km + 3 km = 8 km.

questions.question: A hiker walks 5 km east, then 3 km north. What is the magnitude of their displacement?
questions.explanation: Displacement = √(5² + 3²) = √(25 + 9) = √34 ≈ 5.8 km.

questions.question: Which of the following is a scalar quantity?
questions.explanation: Distance has magnitude only, making it a scalar quantity.

questions.question: A car travels at 60 km/h for 2 hours. How far does it travel?
questions.explanation: Distance = speed × time = 60 km/h × 2 h = 120 km.

questions.question: What is the acceleration of an object that is moving at constant speed in a straight line?
questions.explanation: Constant speed in a straight line means constant velocity, so acceleration is zero.

questions.question: A ball is thrown upward. What happens to its velocity as it rises?
questions.explanation: Gravity causes downward acceleration, so upward velocity decreases while rising.

questions.question: A car goes from 15 m/s to 25 m/s in 4 seconds. What is its average acceleration?
questions.explanation: Acceleration = (25 - 15) m/s / 4 s = 10 m/s / 4 s = 2.5 m/s².

questions.question: Which of the following motions has zero acceleration?
options: A car turning a corner at constant speed
A train moving straight at constant speed
questions.explanation: Only straight-line motion at constant speed has zero acceleration.

questions.question: A person runs 400 m in 80 seconds. What is their average speed?
questions.explanation: Average speed = 400 m / 80 s = 5 m/s.

questions.question: What is instantaneous speed?
options: Average speed over a long time
Total distance divided by total time
questions.explanation: Instantaneous speed is the speed at a particular instant in time.

questions.question: A car's speedometer reads 65 km/h. This represents:
questions.explanation: A speedometer shows the instantaneous speed at that moment.

questions.question: Which graph shows an object at rest?
questions.explanation: A horizontal line (zero slope) on a position-time graph indicates no change in position - the object is at rest.

questions.question: A bicycle accelerates from 4 m/s to 10 m/s over 6 seconds. What is its acceleration?
questions.explanation: Acceleration = (10 - 4) m/s / 6 s = 6 m/s / 6 s = 1.0 m/s².

questions.question: What is the displacement of an object that moves from x = 3 m to x = 8 m?
questions.explanation: Displacement = final position - initial position = 8 m - 3 m = 5 m.

questions.question: A car travels 80 km north, then 60 km south. What is the distance traveled?
questions.explanation: Distance = sum of all paths = 80 km + 60 km = 140 km.

questions.question: A car travels 80 km north, then 60 km south. What is the displacement?
questions.explanation: Displacement = 80 km north - 60 km south = 20 km north.

questions.question: Which of the following is true about acceleration?
options: It is always in the direction of motion
It cannot be zero for a moving object
questions.explanation: Acceleration can be negative (deceleration) when an object slows down.

questions.question: A stone is dropped from a cliff. After 2 seconds, its velocity is 19.6 m/s downward. What is its acceleration?
questions.explanation: Acceleration due to gravity is approximately 9.8 m/s² downward.

questions.question: What does a curved line on a position-time graph indicate?
questions.explanation: A curved position-time graph indicates changing velocity (acceleration).

questions.question: A jogger runs 2 km in 15 minutes, then rests for 5 minutes, then runs 1 km in 8 minutes. What is their average speed for the entire period?
questions.explanation: Total distance = 3 km, total time = 28 minutes = 0.467 hours. Average speed = 3 km / 0.467 h ≈ 6.43 km/h ≈ 6 km/h (closest option).

questions.question: Which of the following motions has constant acceleration?
options: A car turning a corner at constant speed
A ball rolling down a straight ramp
questions.explanation: A ball rolling down a straight ramp has constant acceleration due to gravity.

questions.question: A train increases its speed from 30 m/s to 50 m/s over 100 seconds. What is its acceleration?
questions.explanation: Acceleration = (50 - 30) m/s / 100 s = 20 m/s / 100 s = 0.2 m/s².

questions.question: What is the velocity of an object that moves 20 meters east in 4 seconds?
questions.explanation: Velocity = displacement / time = 20 m east / 4 s = 5 m/s east.

questions.question: Which statement about distance and displacement is correct?
options: Displacement can never be greater than distance
Displacement is always greater than distance
questions.explanation: Displacement is the straight-line distance between start and end points, so it can never exceed the total distance traveled.

questions.question: A car travels 120 km in 1.5 hours. What is its average speed?
questions.explanation: Average speed = 120 km / 1.5 h = 80 km/h.

questions.question: What does a positive slope on a velocity-time graph indicate?
options: The object is moving at constant velocity
questions.explanation: Positive slope on velocity-time graph means velocity is increasing - the object is accelerating.

scoreMessages.90: Excellent! You have mastered motion fundamentals and kinematics.
scoreMessages.70: Very Good! You understand most concepts but should review vector vs scalar quantities.
scoreMessages.50: Good effort! Focus on practicing displacement vs distance and acceleration calculations.
scoreMessages.0: Keep trying! Review the basic definitions and practice simple motion problems.
